name: Wild garlic (ramsons)
notes: Harvest leaves before flowering for best texture/flavour. Beware poisonous lookalikes (e.g., lily-of-the-valley) — confirm by smell (garlic) and ID.

name: Three-cornered leek
notes: Non-native but widespread in parts of the UK. Mild garlic/onion flavour; treat like wild garlic. Confirm ID carefully.

name: Alexanders
notes: Young stems/shoots in spring. Has lookalikes in the carrot family — only eat if you can identify confidently.

name: Stinging nettle (young leaves)
notes: Pick the top 4–6 leaves while young; older leaves can be tougher. Use gloves. Great for soup, pesto, tea.

name: Dandelion leaves
notes: Young leaves are less bitter. Avoid polluted areas and dog-walking hotspots.

name: Chickweed
notes: Tender salad green. Often available in mild winters too.

name: Common sorrel
notes: Lemony leaves; use in moderation (oxalates).

name: Cow parsley (young leaves)
notes: Carrot family has dangerous lookalikes (hemlock). Do not eat unless you can confidently distinguish it.

name: Wild strawberries
notes: Small but intensely flavoured. Pick gently; leave plenty for wildlife.

name: Elderflower
notes: Best in June when flowers are fresh. Use for cordial, fritters, champagne-style drinks.

name: Lime (linden) blossom
notes: Fragrant flowers for tea. Avoid collecting from busy roads due to pollution.

name: Borage (leaves & flowers)
notes: Cucumber-like flavour. Use flowers as garnish; young leaves in salads. Often self-seeds.

name: Wild raspberries
notes: Pick ripe fruit; watch for brambles and ticks in long grass.

name: Blackberries (brambles)
notes: Peak varies by region/weather. Avoid roadside pollution; leave some for wildlife.

name: Rowan berries
notes: Typically cooked (raw berries can be very bitter). Great for jellies.

name: Crab apples
notes: Perfect for jelly. Only pick what you need; check for permission on private land.

name: Elderberries
notes: Cook before eating (raw can upset stomach). Great for syrups and jams.

name: Rosehips
notes: Use for syrups, teas, jellies. Beware irritating hairs inside; strain well.

name: Hawthorn berries (haws)
notes: Traditionally used for ketchups/jellies. Leave plenty for birds; hawthorn is valuable wildlife food.

name: Sloes
notes: Often picked after first frost (or freeze at home) for sloe gin/jelly.

name: Damsons (wild plums)
notes: Great for jams and gin. Only pick where you have access/permission.

name: Hazelnuts
notes: Pick when nuts are full and brown; many will be taken by wildlife quickly.

name: Sweet chestnuts
notes: Collect fallen nuts; beware confusing with horse chestnut (conkers) which are not edible.

name: Beechnuts (beech mast)
notes: Edible in small quantities; high tannins. Roast/soak if using more than a few.

name: Acorns (processed)
notes: Require processing (leaching tannins) before eating. Do not eat raw.

name: Field mushroom (advanced)
notes: Mushroom ID can be dangerous—many toxic lookalikes. Only eat fungi if you are trained and confident.

name: Chanterelle (advanced)
notes: Only forage with confident ID; avoid overharvesting sensitive sites.

name: Giant puffball (advanced)
notes: Only eat when pure white inside. Mushroom ID risks apply.

name: Sea beet
notes: Ancestor of beetroot/chard. Harvest young leaves; avoid polluted shores.

name: Marsh samphire
notes: Often in protected sites—check access rules; harvest lightly. Usually blanched/steamed.

name: Sea aster
notes: Sometimes called 'sea spinach'. Ensure you can access sites legally and safely.

name: Wild garlic flowers
notes: Use flowers as garnish; milder than leaves.

name: Wild chives
notes: Confirm ID; onion scent.

name: Ground elder (young leaves)
notes: Young leaves before they toughen; carrot-family lookalikes exist.

name: Jack-by-the-hedge (garlic mustard)
notes: Peppery/garlicky leaves; pick young.

name: Wild garlic bulbs (not recommended)
notes: Avoid digging bulbs; damages colonies. Prefer leaves.

name: Wood sorrel
notes: Tangy leaves; use sparingly (oxalates).

name: Meadowsweet flowers
notes: Almondy scent; used in cordial/tea.

name: Blackthorn blossom (infusions)
notes: Often used for infusions; pick responsibly.

name: Hawthorn young leaves ('bread and cheese')
notes: Young leaves in spring; avoid thorns.

name: Wild plums
notes: Varies; check ripeness.

name: Wild cherries
notes: Often high up; leave plenty for birds.

name: Bilberries (blaeberries)
notes: Upland heath/woods; stain fingers.

name: Bramble leaves (tea)
notes: Young leaves for tea; avoid sprayed areas.

name: Wild rose petals
notes: Use petals for syrups; ensure unsprayed.

name: Wild mint
notes: Aromatic leaves; many species.

name: Wild thyme
notes: Upland/short turf; aromatic.

name: Porcini/cep (advanced)
notes: Only with confident ID; avoid overpicking.

name: Blackberries (late / northern)
notes: Late season in cooler areas.

name: Wilding apples
notes: Often feral trees; great for sauce/cider.

name: Wilding pears
notes: Some are very gritty/astringent; cook.

name: Green walnuts (pickling)
notes: Pick young for pickling; stains hands.

name: Hop shoots (young)
notes: Young shoots edible; identify properly.

name: Broom flowers (garnish, sparingly)
notes: Use sparingly; some compounds can irritate.

name: Wild garlic seeds
notes: Use like capers when green.

name: Pine needles (tea)
notes: Use for tea; ensure correct ID and avoid yew (toxic).

name: Garlic mustard (jack-by-the-hedge)
notes: Peppery/garlicky leaves; best young in spring.

name: Ground ivy
notes: Aromatic leaves for tea or flavouring; use sparingly.

name: Cleavers (goosegrass)
notes: Young shoots for tea/juice; sieve well if blending.

name: Primrose flowers
notes: Use as garnish; pick lightly (often protected/valued).

name: Wild violets (flowers)
notes: Edible flowers for garnish/syrups; confirm ID.

name: Gorse flowers
notes: Coconut-scented flowers; use sparingly as flavour/garnish.

name: Hawthorn blossom
notes: Can be infused for flavour; avoid picking heavily (wildlife value).

name: Mugwort
notes: Aromatic herb; strong flavour; use sparingly.

name: Yarrow
notes: Aromatic herb; used in teas; avoid if allergic to daisies.

name: Ribwort plantain
notes: Young leaves in salads/soups; older leaves tougher.

name: Broadleaf plantain
notes: Young leaves edible; often in paths—avoid polluted areas.

name: Wild marjoram (oregano)
notes: Aromatic herb; pick flowering tops/leaves.

name: Elder leaves (young)
notes: Traditionally used sparingly; not commonly eaten—prefer flowers/berries.

name: Sweet cicely (advanced)
notes: Aniseed flavour. Carrot-family ID caution.

name: Wild carrot seeds (advanced)
notes: Only with confident ID; dangerous lookalikes in Apiaceae.

name: Wild fennel (coastal)
notes: Aromatic fronds and seeds; coastal/roadsides—avoid pollution.

name: Sea kale (young shoots)
notes: Often protected; do not pick where restricted. Young shoots edible.

name: Sea radish
notes: Peppery leaves/flowers; ensure correct ID and clean sites.

name: Sea purslane
notes: Salty leaves; harvest lightly in safe, legal areas.

name: Sea lettuce (seaweed)
notes: Rinse well; collect from clean waters and observe local rules.

name: Dulse (seaweed)
notes: Edible seaweed; collect from clean waters; rinse well.

name: Pepper dulse (seaweed)
notes: Garlicky seaweed; collect responsibly.

name: Bladderwrack (seaweed)
notes: Seaweed used for stocks; harvest lightly and rinse well.

name: Kelp (seaweed, various)
notes: Collect washed-up or cut sparingly where allowed; rinse thoroughly.

name: Wood blewit (advanced)
notes: Mushroom ID risk: only eat with expert confirmation.

name: Hedgehog mushroom (advanced)
notes: Mushroom ID risk: only eat with expert confirmation.

name: Oyster mushroom (advanced)
notes: Found on dead hardwoods; ID risk applies.

name: Wood ear (advanced)
notes: Often on elder; ID risk applies.

name: Jelly ear (advanced)
notes: Same as wood ear; use with confident ID.

name: Morel (advanced)
notes: Must be cooked; ID risk applies.

name: St George's mushroom (advanced)
notes: Spring mushroom; ID risk applies.

name: Winter chanterelle / yellowfoot (advanced)
notes: Autumn/winter fungus; ID risk applies.

name: Hawthorn young leaves
notes: Young spring leaves sometimes eaten raw; thorny shrub.

name: Dock (young leaves)
notes: Use very young leaves; older can be tough; oxalates.

name: Wild garlic seed pods (green)
notes: Pick green seed pods before they harden; use like capers.

name: Lime (linden) young leaves
notes: Tender spring leaves sometimes used as salad green.

name: Birch sap
notes: Tapped in early spring; do not over-tap trees.

name: Birch leaves (young)
notes: Young leaves for tea; use moderately.

name: Spruce tips
notes: Citrusy young tips; ensure correct ID (not yew).

name: Beech leaves (young)
notes: Young leaves can be eaten raw; older become tough.

name: Sweet woodruff (advanced)
notes: Traditional flavouring; use sparingly.

name: Meadow vetchling (young shoots, advanced)
notes: Pea-family; only eat with confident ID.

name: Wild asparagus (advanced)
notes: Rare in the wild; only pick where legal and abundant.

name: Wild horseradish (root, advanced)
notes: Strong root; use sparingly; ensure correct ID.

name: Burdock root (advanced)
notes: Dig first-year roots; avoid polluted soils; identify correctly.

name: Blackberries (early)
notes: Earlier season in warmer areas.

name: Serviceberries (Juneberry)
notes: Often planted in parks/gardens; berries edible when dark.

name: Mulberries
notes: Often from old garden trees; stains; collect with permission.

name: Gorse (seeds, advanced)
notes: Not commonly eaten; included for completeness—research carefully.

name: Sweet briar rosehips
notes: Rosehips similar use; aromatic leaves too.

name: Whitebeam berries (advanced)
notes: Some Sorbus fruits need bletting/cooking; only with good ID.

name: Medlars (bletted)
notes: Need bletting (softening) before eating; often old garden trees.

name: Sea buckthorn berries
notes: Very tart orange berries on thorny shrubs; coastal dunes.

name: Shaggy inkcap (advanced)
notes: Only eat very fresh; must not be confused with toxic inkcaps.

name: Guelder rose berries (advanced)
notes: Often cooked; bitter; confirm ID (not for beginners).

name: Pine nuts (not typical UK)
notes: Included only if you have access to edible pine nuts; most UK pines are not practical sources.

name: Saffron milk cap (advanced)
notes: Only with expert ID; associated with pine.

name: Field blewit (advanced)
notes: Only with expert ID.

name: Pignut tubers (advanced)
notes: Digging damages habitat; Apiaceae ID risk. Not recommended for beginners.

name: Watercress (wild, advanced)
notes: Only harvest from clean running water; risk of liver fluke contamination in some waters.

name: Fat hen
notes: Young leaves like spinach; common arable weed.

name: Corn salad (lamb's lettuce)
notes: Tender salad leaves; often in fields/disturbed ground.

name: Common purslane
notes: Succulent leaves; often on disturbed ground; avoid contamination.

name: Wild blackcurrants (where present)
notes: Usually from gardens/wildings; pick with permission.

name: Wild redcurrants (where present)
notes: Often garden escapes; pick with permission.

name: Gooseberries (wildings)
notes: Often from old gardens; pick with permission.

name: Common salsify (root, advanced)
notes: Often from old cultivation; identify carefully.

name: Wild parsnip (advanced)
notes: Sap can cause phytophotodermatitis; Apiaceae risk—avoid unless expert.

name: Bracken fiddleheads (not recommended)
notes: Not recommended due to toxicity concerns; included for awareness.

name: Reedmace (cattail) shoots (advanced)
notes: Shoots and pollen can be edible; harvest from clean waters only.

name: Reedmace pollen (advanced)
notes: Pollen can be used as flour supplement; collect from clean sites.

name: Elderflower (early)
notes: Earlier flowering in warm areas; pick fresh blossoms.

name: Elderflower (late)
notes: Later flowering in cooler regions.

name: Blackthorn young leaves (advanced)
notes: Not a common edible; included for completeness; thorns; ID well.
